columns.text: In this task, **we should find the coupon rates of Chamberlain Co. company.**

We can classify yield to maturity as a return rate. More specifically, yield to maturity is what an investor will earn if he holds the bond until the maturity date when the issuer pays back all the promised interest payments and the amount of the debt written in the contract (principal). In our case, it is 8 percent. We can say that this is a nominal interest rate at the annual level

We should calculate the future payment of the bond, discounted at the time zero (now). The bond payment will be twice per year(semiannually), but we have an annual coupon rate and YTM. That is why we should divide the YTM and the coupon rate by two. A period is given annually, but we should multiply it by two. The bondholder will not get payments 20 times, but 40 (two times per year).

Let's adjust the coupon rate.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{semiannual coupon rate}&=\dfrac{\text{annual coupon rate}}{2}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{6\%}{2}\\[15pt]
&=3\%
\end{aligned}$$

The semi-annual coupon rate is 3\%.

Let's calculate the value of the coupon with the new coupon rate.
Coupon rates are determined by the entity that issues a bond. The coupon value will be the same for every future payment. So it is a fixed amount. We do not know the face value of the bond so let's assume it is \$1,000.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{coupon value}=&\text{coupon rate}\times\text{Face value}\\[15pt]
&=3\%\times\$1,000\\[15pt]
&=\$30
\end{aligned}$$

The coupon value is \$30.

Let's adjust the period.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{semiannual periods}&=\text{years}\times2\\[15pt]
&=20\times2\\[15pt]
&=40
\end{aligned}$$

We should consider 40 periods.

Now we have all adjusted data to solve the requirement.

$$\text{Price}=\text{C}\times\dfrac{1-\left(1+\text{YTM}\right)^\text{-n}}{\text{YTM}}+\dfrac{\text{P}}{\left(1+\text{YTM}\right)^\text{n}}$$

C-coupon of the bond 

YTM-yield to maturity

P-par value

n-time

Let's insert the data in the previous formula.

$$\$1,083=\$30\times\dfrac{1-\left(1+\text{YTM}\right)^{-40}}{\text{YTM}}+\dfrac{\$1,000}{\left(1+\text{YTM}\right)^{40}}$$

**The YTM of the bond is 5.321\%.**

Now, we have to calculate the coupon rates if the bond is selling at the par value. We have to use our calculation for YTM and plug it into the following formula.

$$\begin{aligned}
\$1,000&=\text{C}\times\dfrac{1-\left(1+5.321\%\right)^{-40}}{5.321\%}+\dfrac{\$1,000}{\left(1+5.321\%\right)^{40}}\\[15pt]
\$1,000&=\text{C}\times16.43+\$125.73\\[15pt]
\text{C}&=\dfrac{\$1,000-\$125.73}{16.43}\\[15pt]
&=\$53.207
\end{aligned}$$

**The coupon value is \$53.207.**

To get the coupon rates, we should \$53.207 (coupon value) divide by the \$1,000 (face value).

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{coupon rate}&=\dfrac{\$53.207}{\$1,000}\times100\\[15pt]
&=0.0532\times100\\[15pt]
&=\boxed{5.3207\%}
\end{aligned}$$

**If the company wants to sell the bond at par value should have 5.3207\% coupon rates.**
